bboxes.raw_text:
PHILADELPHIA, Miss. = The
search continues for the three
missing civil rights workers.
More than 400 sailors and several
local officers have tracked
through the marshes and nearby
areas. Helicopters have been
used, too.


A door to door check of resi-
dents in the town has proved
fruitless. Search leaders are
baffled at the lack of clues to the
disappearance of Mich eel
Schwerner, "a, AndrewG Goldman,
20 both white New Workers., and
James Clancy. % a Negro from
Meridian, Miss.

The signing of the federal civil
rights bill by President Lyndon
Johnson was the signal for
Negroes to begin testing 1t.


In Birmingham. Ala, Jackson
Vile, Fla. and many other SOUTH
ern cities, Negroes were permit
ted to enter and eat in previously
segregated restaurants.


In Atlanta, Ca. a restaurant
owner, Lester Maddox, pulled out
his pistol and prevented three
Negroes from entering his place.
An angry mob of whites cheered
as the Negroes stayed inside their
car and drove away.


On July 4th. Negroes were
peacefully integrated in Mont
gomery, Ala, Memphis. Tenn,
and Petersburg. Va. Cities in
Georgia. including Americas, Al
bany and Valdosta were scenes of
migration without incidents.

Clyde Joe Wright, Is. is the
Arizona Tribune Teen of the
Week. He earned this choice for
winning three scholarship awards
last month when he completed his
senior year at Phoenix Union
High School.


Joe, Is, moved here four years
ago from Lockhart, Texas. He
maintained high grades while he
was on the high school track team
at PU.


He won the Sperry Rand. the
Inez Fairfax and the Cow Bellies
scholarships. Joe plans to enter
Arizona State University this fall.
He would like to be a doctor.


Joe lives with his sister and
brether-in law Mr.. and Mrs.
Selby James, 23ll E. Wier.

SAN FRANCISCO Whitney
Young. Jr.. executive director Of
the National Urban League, told
an audience at the 24th annual
National Newspaper Publisher
Assn, convention that they should
"chart a course editorially be-
tween ultra conservative leaders
who would halt all protests and the
ultra militant one who would have
Negroes picketing every day.


Young continued, "a leader
who documents charges Of dis
elimination against Negroes bya
manufacturer and leads sue
cessful boycott to remove 1t, is
worthy Of our support. But, so
is the leader who urges Negroes
to qualify themselves tohold down
jobs in that company


The UL leader stressed that
implanted and sporadic demon
strations just for the sake Of pub
licity we're of less value than no
demonstrations. He felt that
more effort should be made tobe
sure that some leaders we're not
merely seeking personal glory.


He concluded, "It Is not enough
to have dramatic efforts, it is
necessary to have dramatic re-
SultS,''

I'll Heed


Addresses NNPA
At oath Meet

WASHINGTON The National
Labor Relations Boards ruling
that discrimination by labor
unions is an unfair labor prac-
tice, is "a most significant
peterborough" NAACPGeneral
Counsel Robert L. Carter said.


He continued. NEGRO workers
may obtain, without cost through
the facilities of the NLRB, pro-
lection against trade union dis
elimination. The new ruling con-
strues unions duty of fair rep
resentation as barring segrega-
ted locals and exclusion Of Negro
employees in the bargaining unit
from membership in the union."


Under previous Board decis-
ions. only discrimination on the
grounds of union membership or
non-membership was held to be
an unfair labor practice. The
Boards new decision affirmed an
earlier ruling by the trial exami-
ner.


Further protection is provided
Negro union members under Sec
ton 8 (b) (3), of the Act, the
NAACP counsel pointed out. The
ruling. he said, places a dutyto
bargain on the union which is
owed not only to the employer,
but also the employees 1t rep
resents.


ut Is the Boards most force
full statement of the position that
unions have an obligation to enter
into contracts with the employer
which do not discriminate against
any employee on the basis of his
color"

Labor Ruling Is


Herald By NAACP

SEATTLE = Mrs. Elizabeth D.
Koontz, a Negro of Salisbury,
NC, was chosen president-elect
of the Department of Classroom
Teachers, at the National Educa-
ton Ass ociation convention last
week. She will assume duties In
June, 1865.

BARSTOW. Fla. Charlie
Smith, a former slave, celebrated
his l22nd birthday on July fourth.
He is the Oldest man listed on the
social security rolls.


Charlie was kidnapped from

From the sVindOWs of the municipal
building q large area can be seen where
substandayd housing, few city parks and
Fairgrounds and high crime and juvenile
delinquency rates abound.


Within the areas are crowded schools
which are unable to byOUide many modern
facilities because of the high tax rates and
lou assessed property UaluatiOns.


Where are those city facilities which
could haze been started last spring Where
are the city pools and parks Which could
haze been created? Where are the city
branches Of the public library?


The mayor has announced the 'ObeY0-
ton LEA Pr program, but something
could and should haze been accOnbl ished
before this summer.


Lines Of boys are stiu tbunabi,ag rides
on the corners trying to reach E0stl0ke
Park for a saOina. HXadyeds still CROWD
the inadequate Fairgrounds held at the
schools and hundreds more stin pay IN
the streets and on vacant lots.


Summer is here and looking SOuthO0Td,
there is still little to ShOaO for the number
of months that most Of the elmer city,
has been wit1ain the city limits. Mind you,
large part of this area has been within
the city jurisdiction for more than tp0o
years.


Let as make an effort to obtain city
parks, pools, community centeTs and
library facilities for this area. OPERA
tiOn LEA P certainly has several start
ing points.

Liberia at the age of IL and he
was sold to a Texas rancher
who gave him his name and raised
him.


When Mr.. Smith was given his
freedom. he chose July the Fourth
as his birthday.

Many Of dedicated Phoenix decided
do something for their community In l9 teacher Mrs.
Margaret Washington. s organized the Mary
Bethune League.


Sunday reunion of of the charter league members
the home of Mrs. Madge Copeland.


From left Mesdames M. E. Copeland president Carrie
Dericks Kemp secretary Washington miss Leg founde
Mary King and Lille JONES' corresponding secretary

article "a Negro Alliance for Progress which appeared
the June issue of the Negro Digest.


The Mary Bee League has purchased property 18th
E. Jefferson for the purpose of building community

highligh the 34h Elks Pacific States
regional Phoenix recently the
awarding of the scholarship South Mountain High
graduate.


Mrs. Nee B. Smith, grand daughter ruler of the womens d.
of the Eks of New York watches Grand Exalted Ruler Hob
Reynolds of Philadelphia, the award Howard Kirk,
Jr. regional oratorical contest winner.


Howard, the Mr.. Mrs. Howard Kirk Sr 1902 E.
Atlanta participating speech for the four
than 20 trophies dozen plaques and
scrapbook full Of certificates.


He will attend the national Elks speech Miami Fla,
month.
